reviewText:
Soldier Front 2 is without a doubt the best F2P FPS experience i've ever come across. (And FPS is my main genre with quite a bit of experience) It in many ways manages to match and in some places exceed both its F2P brethren as well as its more costly retail alternatives. SF2 is as you can tell, is a sequel to a once very successful F2P title back in 2004/2007 in Korea & later internationally by the name of Soldier Front/Special Force. This game manages to not only outdo its (very) dated predecessor but also remain a viable option in todays overpopulated shooter scene. Everything from the animations, guns, and gameplay very closely mimics its big brother Call of Duty, and does a damn good job at delivering the same experience without paying every year for a new edition (map packs included). The game oozes quality and definitely is the best you can get when it comes to free to play currently at the moment if you're looking for COD-style shooters.

THE GOOD
+ Fantastic presentation & graphics for a F2P.
+ Weapons are affordable with ingame cash & permanent.
+ Quality COD-Style fast-paced gameplay.
+ A slew of modes to choose from including Classic Defusal to Coop.
+ Entertaining for both newbies and pros alike.
+ Tons of people playing all the time.

THE BAD
- Sometimes laggy players ruin a good match
- Hacking players can be a pain in the ♥♥♥.
- Community is horrible and abusive to eachother. (They crossed over from the first game)
- No way to mute/report/kick undesirable players.
- Female characters run faster and are harder to hit.

THE UGLY
Raging 12 year olds from the philippines who constantly spam the chat with incoherent things like aw" "vovo" and "base"

BOTTOM LINE
I can hardly think of any free-to-play shooters that manage to compare with full retail games this well. It's very impressive if you enjoy COD-Style shooters. If they managed to fix the hacking problem
date: the game would be perfect.\n\nHighly Recommended. 9/10"

reviewText:
It's a good alternative to Call of Duty. Well, think of it as COD...but free (I actually prefer this).

I would rate this 8/10. It's fun, easy to pick up and weekly updates/maitanance, requires skill (no aim assist) compared to COD.

############# FULL REVIEW #############

I'll start with the positive things about the game.

- It's easy and fast to learn and pick up at any time.
- Infinite replay value
- Great gun play. All guns require some degree of practice to be able to use properly and they all a very different from each other. Some guns will require a lot more skill to master than others.
- The graphics are decent and run really well on most computers. They're aren't amazing however.   Definitely not blockbuster or AAA.
- The weekly event system is awesome as it encourages the player to try new things and get rewards for them. They even give away things such as SP (in game currency) just for logging in!
- Monthly updates and maintenance which brings new content.
- The variety of guns is great. There is a gun for everybodies play style.
- The new weapon camo system is pretty neat as it allows for some degree of weapon customisation.
- The maps are designed quite well, the maps are from small to medium sized which allows for intense fighting in close quarters. Pretty much every map has parts in which people who like to fight at range can take advantage of also.
- If you buy a weapon from the game shop it is permanent. Unless you sell it of course.
- I love the different game modes this has to offer, such as slaughter which involves one team playing as aliens and the other as humans, Smash with involves two teams of players fighting on three layers of easily broken glass. If a player falls through all three layers they go plummeting down to a spike floor with a small chance of landing on a moving bouncy pad and getting back into the fight. There are the regular Team Deathmatch, Deathmatch, Sabotage (planting and defusing a bomb) and seizure (capturing an item) game modes too.

Some things I'm not too impressed by

- The menu system is a bit off, It doesn't properly run in full screen mode and can be hard to navigate around at first, but overall quite bearable.
- The rental system is a bit annoying. You can't buy permanently owned character items - you have to rent them for a certain amount of days.
- No weapon upgrade system
- If you want special skinned weapons with EO tech and ACOG sights you have to win them by gambling which means spending AP (Aeria Points) which costs actual money. I could buy 100 capsules/tokens and never receive a single permanent item, just some rental gun. They do give away free capsules every now and then which is good.
- The odd glitch such as disappearing HUD and camera not functioning properly is a bit of a pain. Good thing it doesn't happen often.
- The mamba character. This is some blonde chick in some tight clothing in high heels. It's a sexist portrayal of women in combat. The male characters in this game are all wearing combat gear.


The gameplay is this: Kill or be killed. It's easy to kill and easy to be killed. There is no aim assist. So if you can't aim for headshots you're dead. Thats about it.
If you're new to this kind of game don't worry, there are servers dedicated for you to get to grips with the game. Once you're good enough you'll graduate and move onto the open servers.

Some people think this game is Pay to Win". I think not because you don't actually need some fancy AUG Mk4 weapon to win. Many of the best pro players use the basic AK 103 and M4a1 given to player from the start. The special paid guns do make it easier but you don't actually need them to be good at the game.  The special weapons
date: character items and VIP subscription may help you to a extent but you can still be very bad at the game and lose to a player who pays nothing.\n\nAbout hackers
recommended: there are a few out there but not too many. Most people kick them from the game and are dealt with quickly. So you don't have to really worry about them.\n\nHope that wasn't too long."

reviewText:
This is a lengthy review, so scroll downf or a full report!

Having played this game a fair bit and getting up to level 26 in-game, I can say that this is well-worth the time and effort to play. I've played a large number of free to play shooters out there (nearly all of the most popular ones) and this one is the only one that can deliver on most bases successfully.

The biggest issue that seems to trouble most FPS games out there today (speaking FREE TO PLAY FPS games) are cash-shop imbalances, and currency gains.  Some games deliver on one, but lack on gameplay or maps, or somewhere else. At least that's what it feels like, Soldier Front 2's cash shop items are primarily cosmetic differences fromt heir normal counter parts. The stats on the weapons are listed and you can compare the regular weapons to the premium weapons, at most the differences are a different skin and occasionally a different optic which can also be obtained through buying the advanced version of each weapon through gameplay. It takes longer, but it is not game-breaking by ANY means. I myself, prefer good ol' iron sights as I'm sure plenty of others do as well.

On that topic, let me talk about the currency system. You start out with plenty enough to buy your first weapon, and maybe even a secondary weapon that are -permanent-. There's not that many weapons in the game compared to some other shooters out there, but it comes at the cost of all the weapons being relatively balanced and even with that in mind there is still a solid variety of weapons to choose from. The choice of the weapon you use is almost always dependant on your preference via aiming patterns, recoil, rate of fire, etc. Whatever suits your playstyle. The currency gains had me worried at first, though the following week I decided to give it another go and check out the weekly missions and all of my concerns were alleviated. On top of the traditional SP guage that fills up gradually as you play (some of you may remember from Soldier Front 1), the missions grant you these capsules which grant you items, currency, and different cosmetic things as well. You can win up to 1,000,000 SP from a single capsule. After playing for only a couple of hours, I was able to buy two different weapons and have SP left over.

A couple of things to note before you read the pros and cons, is that Soldier Front 2 does not offer weapon customization like other games may include such as Call of Duty, or A.v.A. or Combat Arms, instead it offers 5 slightly altered versions of the weapon you are using that you may purchase. For example, say you started with the AK-107, you will start with a basic version of the weapon. As you gain more kills with it, at certain intervals (75, 150, etc. as examples, not actual numbers) you will unlock AK-107 Version 2, which will be the same weapon with an increased rate of fire at the cost of some firepower. Later versions offer similar give and take versions, such as more fire power at the cost of rate of fire, or magazine size at the cost of weight as you get more kills with that weapon. While this does not seem as creative or fun as some other games, what you result in is a very balanced weapon progression system that ensures competitive gameplay across the board. I prefer the competitive nature of the game at the cost of pretty weapons, all day every day. If tinkering with guns is your thing, I would suggestion Blacklight: Retribution anyway.

The other thing to note is that headshots are REWARDED. The hitbox for the head in this game is NOTABLY smaller than in other shooters. This will be plainly obvious for you to see, but you are rewarded for taking those shots! Spraying into someone at a distance may cause your rounds to be scattered and it may feel like they're just super tanky and you can't do anything to take them down, but one shot to the head and they are gone. The difference is very noticeable, aiming for the head becomes a second nature while playing this game. What you're thinking might be Oh well I always aim for the head

reviewText:
Soldier Front 2 is overall a fun, fast paced action game with inspiration from games like Battlefield and Call of Duty.

Weapons
------------
Soldier Front 2's weapons feel powerful and heavy, such as in all good FPS games. Most guns are heavy hitters as a starter assault rifle or pistol does about 60%-70% damage PER SHOT! Sniping is respectably easier in Soldier Front 2 which allows many people to become the accurate damage dealers that they wish to become. Most weapons are purchasable through just playing the game and earning SP (The in-game currency). You can buy and funnel real-life currency into the game and that will obviously give you the edge over starter or beginner players, but I have on several occasions defeated and dominated players that have custom or bought weapons, So there is no worries if you cannot afford getting high powered expensive weapons.

Maps
--------
The maps within Soldier Front 2, have a certain something to be desired but offer a good gaming experience. Several maps are just killhouses" such as "Dam" which allows enemy snipers on several occasions and several different vantage spots to camp senceless and pick off any clueless victims. There are better and bigger maps such as "Farm" and "Riverside" which is long range tactical 8v8 experience that leaves the player feeling happy with his/her progress and kills.

Customisation
----------------
There is a wide range of customisation options in Soldier Front 2 that lets the player become his/her own soldier and create his/her own character instead of being a randomly generated soldier in such games as Call of Duty. reviewText:
A pleasantly surprising free game, Soldier Front 2 doesn't really try anything new, but it plays well for Generic Modern FPS #174.

A mesh between CoD and CS, where you can successfully run and gun like a fool if you wish, but against a skilled player you'll lose to headshots everytime. Game modes consist of classic modes like Team Deathmatch, Sabotage (pretty much classic CS game mode), Corp Battles (clan battles) and a survival based mode vs aliens.  The game is not pay to win if you're decent at shooters, the payed guns are only marginally better than the free ones,  and there's a wide selection of perfectly viable free guns anyway (in fact one of the most popular guns is one of the default starter guns).

Cons would be that the UI feels very cluttered and confusing at first, and the game does push store items in your face often, but there's pretty much no reason to buy anything from there excpt cosmetics.

Overall I give it a 6/10, as there's still room for improvement, but it ain't half bad for a free game.

(Before you read this, i'd just like to let you know SOLDIER FRONT 2 IS DEAD RIP RIP RIP RIP YOU CANT PLAY IT ITS CLOSING DOWN RIP RIP RIP. But if you would like to read my review go ahead. It was truly an unreplacable game) Soldier front 2 is an FPS game. It is basically a free version of Call Of Duty Black Ops II. Made by Aeria games, Soldier Front 2 focuses on multiplayer battles instead of single player battles like Black Ops II in the campaign. Soldier Front 2 has amazing graphics and stunning features.

The guns in soldier front 2 have good and balanced damage, weight, firing rate and recoil makes gameplay smooth and great to play. The maps are well designed and they are easy to learn so being good at the game is based entirely on skill. Soldier Front 2 has developed their guns well with great skins and phenomenol muzzle flash. The lightiing isn't too bright or too dark and you can easily set the game options with a few clicks. The guns look realistic and the first person perspective makes everything look lively however, the guns are really similar  to Call Of Duty Black Ops II. There are dual guns and guns similar to ACRs, M4s and lots others.

The game has lots of game modes such as alien survival, alien defense, competetive, open, newbie and . Aliens in Soldier Front 2 are called Xanthid. Xanthid survival is where aliens start swarming in from everywhere and you must survive for the longest time. Xanthid defense is where Xanthid invade your territory and you must kill them and complete waves while defending your core. Competetive channel is for hardcore players who play competetively to gain titles and earn a good reputation. Open channel is for all ranks for noob levels to pro levels. Newbie channel is for players who have just started playing the game or are for people wanting to troll beginners. Finally, the Xanthid hero mode is basically like league of legends in first person shooter mode. To win you must destroy the other teams nexus by buying guns, perks, upgrades and farming mobs/players/turrets.

To conclude everything, this game is awesome! Great graphics, great gameplay, great guns, great maps, great features and great game modes. Recommended for everyone of all ages. Can be played by kids in the newbie channels and can be played by teenagers/adults in the open/competetive channels.

reviewText: Another FPS that could easily be called a CoD clone in many regards but a well executed one at that.  Now granted,  when this game has to compete with other F2P games like Warface, Ghost Recon Phantoms, Blacklight Retribution (to name a few from my library) it doesnt really stand out too well from the pack in most of its game modes.  That's not to say the game is bad, quite the contrary actually.  I thoroughly enjoyed Soldier Front 2.  The graphics are definitely good enough to get a passing grade, the maps are good, and everything feels as it should in an FPS.  But for the longest time for me there wasnt really anything to set this game apart from the countless other shooters I could play.  Then I found Hero mode.  To my knowledge this is still the only game (or at least the only F2P game) with this mode or anything similar to it.  Hero mode  imo is to Soldier Front 2 as Zombies" is to Call of Duty.  Hero mode is so much fun and what truly sets this game apart from ANY other FPS I've ever played and it alone makes the download worthwhile.  a mix between a MOBA and a FPS is such a good idea that I am truly surprised no one thought of it sooner.  Hero mode is something I definitely want to play more of and is quite honestly the only reason I keep SF2 in my library.  While developer Dragonfly may not have revolutionized the shooter as we know it much like Halo or Call of Duty both did in their own regards
date:
Soldier Front 2 definitely breaks some new ground that is worth investing some time into with Hero mode.

Overall game: 6/10 great game but nothing really special imo
Hero mode:  8.5/10 the one exception to the above statement"

reviewText:
Soldier Front 2 is simply a game that targets a larger market- the Call of Duty-esque fanbase. Veterans from Soldier Front 1 will get some nostalgia and enjoyment out of the upgraded new maps, however gunplay is simple and objects seem generic. Overall, Soldier Front 2 is an easier game, but unfaithful to the original.

-PROS-
> The SP you gain from matches is now more than you need to repair, making characters finally self-sufficient, not needing to rely on SP recharges, Super Booms, AP+/PA+ points, or equipment. SP is also much more easier to come by, allowing you to try out different playing styles.
> Guns are more balanced and open to multiple play, allowing different set-ups to work more effectively on certain maps. The variant/modification system provides you more out of the gun that you may already like.
> The fresh upgrade on original SF1 maps provide so much more gameplay compared to the original.
> Various annoyances from the original are corrected in this version of SF2.
> Pay 2 Win is less apparent and isn't very likely to affect gameplay too much.
> Pistols can play a valuable role. Both standard pistols and the legendary Desert Eagle feel worthwhile to buy and wield.

-CONS-
> Gunplay is simplistic and generic. It combines a little bit of CoD with the CS series, but not enough to roll it to either end. This awkward child recoil DOESN'T compliment either ironsights/hipfire, lowering the value of gunplay to both CoD and CS fans.
> Headshots are not always consistent. There are damage differences in the head depending on which side you fire it at.
> Grenades have little value in play due to the indicator. Flashbangs are effective but obvious. Smoke Grenades have no actual purpose. Standard HE grenades are triumphed by the more expensive Incindiary Grenade.
> Movement fell onto the sprint-button trope. It results in less emphasis on weapon switching and knives cannot be 'wielded'
> Objectives still feel worthless to go after. Although it puts tension on the defending team, it ends up just involving defenders abandoning their base to stay at the attacker's spawn.
> Although the map's graphics are upgraded and slightly tweaked, they aren't competitive ready. Spots can still be easily camped to gain immediate map dominance.
> The new wall-exploding gimmick isn't fully fleshed out and extremely loud.
> Hit-Detection is extremely poor and laggy. Like CS:GO except 16tick and on a constant 200ping.

Overall Soldier Front 2 is a different game under the same franchise. Most gameplay feels raw, awkward, or clunky and has few redeeming factors. However, Soldier Front 2 is still a decent play due to a well-tuned gun/modification system that gives a reason to dedicate to your lover gun. Soldier Front 2 gets a 4/10.

reviewText:
This is the sequel to the original South Korean F2P MMOFPS which had an insane amount of skill requirement and map familiarity. Every minor to major update made players rethink their playstyles, which weapons they should use, and had a very dedicated community alongside and because of it. It wasn't a very content-heavy, graphically impressive, or technically advanced game. In fact, it was a poor man's CS 1.6 clone, but it was still extremely good because of it. It barely had seasonal costumes added to keep it fresh and the maps were few but familiar which kept the fact that new maps took years to get more tolerable as each was designed so well that every game felt different from the rest.

The sequel remains faithful to the series by retaining the original maps, gameplay types, and weapon advantages while adding modern staples like ironsights, sprinting, and newer gameplay modes like survival, endless team deathmatches, and sniper duels. It still doesn't get content updates fast enough, but that doesn't really matter to the community that enjoys this game.

I personally love this game for staying true to the original's vision and retaining the same flavor that was unlike other FPS's from that time and to this day.

Play this game, if you don't like it then move on, you'll find greener albeit different pastures. If you do, congratulations and I'll see you on the battlefield, soldier.

reviewText:
Rating -- 8/10

Review -- SoldierFront 2 is a free to play game developed by the South Korean developer Dragonfly and published by Aeria games. This game, in my opinion, combines elements from Counter-Strike and those of arcade shooters such as Call of Duty. This game features 5 game channel -- Newbie, Open, Competitive, Xanthid, and Hero Mode. Newbie is for all players under the rank of 47. Open is for everyone, although the skill based is definitely higher than that of the Newbie channel. Competitve is mostly for corps (clan) battles, but also has a corps recruting channel to try to get new corps members. Xanthid mode reminds me of the Zombies mode from Black Ops, but it is different and quite fun. It has two modes, Survival and Defense. Survival is wave after wave after wave with now defensive barriers to help you. Survive 30 wave and win. Defense has you protecting a node from wave of xanthids. Easy mode -- defend against 15 waves, Normal mode -- defend against 20 waves. Now, it also has a Hard mode and Hell mode which can be unlocked, but I have yet to do so. The last mode, and the cetainly most interestin mode, is Hero mode. Hero mode is essentially a League of Legends or Dota 2 game, but in first person. It can be a 3v3 (recomended), 4v4, or 5v5. Players and team xanthids have to destroy enimy turrets and thier node, while protecting their own.
This game also features a very good shop. You rank up to unloack the weapons, and use SP (in game currency) to buy them. Now, if you want to, you can pay real money for AP. AP can get you a very limited amount of items straight up. Only 3 weapons are available for AP. You can get a VIP cupon to get better looking items of ones you can get with SP. To get the good items, you have to take a chance. You buy 1, 6, or 12 lottery tickets, and you can get either a really good gun, or some crap. The good items have a small chance of actually getting. Now, there are also some lottery tickets you can get with SP, and you can have a chance to get some weapons that rival those that you have to pay real money for.
I highly recomend this game, and since it's free, there is no reason you shouldn't at least give it a try. :D

The sequel remains faithful to the series by retaining the original maps, gameplay types, and weapon advantages while adding modern staples like ironsights, sprinting, and newer gameplay modes like survival, endless team deathmatches, and sniper duels. It still doesn't get content updates fast enough, but that doesn't really matter to the community that enjoys this game.

I personally love this game for staying true to the original's vision and retaining the same flavor that was unlike other FPS's from that time and to this day.

Play this game, if you don't like it then move on, you'll find greener albeit different pastures. If you do, congratulations and I'll see you on the battlefield, soldier.
